hadiths.english_translation: [This entry contains only a companion name with no complete hadith: Umayr al-Abdi (may Allah be pleased with him)]

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only a companion name with no chain of transmission or hadith text. It appears to be a section header or fragment rather than a complete hadith.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Al-Ash'ath ibn Umayr: The delegation of Abdul-Qais came to the Prophet ﷺ. When they intended to depart, they said: We have memorized everything we heard from the Prophet ﷺ. Then they asked him about Nabidh (fermented drink). They said: O Messenger of Allah, we are in a land of filthy climate, and nothing cures us except drink. He said: What is your drink? They said: Nabidh. He said: In what do you drink it? They said: In al-Naqir (a hollowed tree trunk). He said: Do not drink from al-Naqir. Then they went out, and they said: By Allah, our people will not accept this from us. So they returned and asked him again. He said to them similarly. Then they repeated, and he said to them: Do not drink from al-Naqir, for a man among you might strike his cousin a blow from which he will remain lame until the Day of Resurrection. Then they laughed. He said: Why do you laugh? They said: O Messenger of Allah, by the One who sent you with truth, we drank from a Naqir of ours, and one of us struck another a blow from which he remained lame until the Day of Resurrection.

narrators.name: Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shayba
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Shayba Ibrahim al-Kufi

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl ibn Ghazwan al-Dahhak

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl is graded as Da'if (weak) - this is a critical weakness in the chain
Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib is known as a mudallis (type 3) and narrates using عَنْ (ambiguous transmission term), which requires caution
Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) in the latter part of the chain from Ata' onwards

potential_issues.issue: Presence of weak narrator (Da'if): Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl
potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn al-Fudayl is classified as Da'if (weak) by multiple scholars including Yahya ibn Ma'in and Abu Hatim. His criticism for errors in transmission directly affects the reliability of this hadith.

potential_issues.issue: Mudallis narrator with indirect transmission: Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib
potential_issues.impact: Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib is classified as a Category 3 mudallis by Ibn Hajar and narrates via عَنْ (indirect term), which introduces ambiguity in the connection to his teacher. While he is generally considered acceptable (Saduq), this combination requires caution.
From Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib onwards, the chain uses عَنْ (indirect transmission), creating potential for disconnections in the chain.

Topics: Incident of the delegation of Abdul-Qais visiting the Prophet ﷺ
Question about drinking Nabidh (fermented drink)
Prohibition of drinking from al-Naqir (hollowed tree trunk)
Warning about consequences of drinking from al-Naqir
Incident of a man striking his cousin with lasting injury

hadiths.english_translation: [This entry contains only a companion name with no complete hadith: Marwad ibn Dhabyan al-Saduси (may Allah be pleased with him)]

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only a companion name with no chain of transmission or hadith text. It appears to be a section header or fragment rather than a complete hadith.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Qatadah: Marwad ibn Dhabyan, one of the Banu Sadu', (may Allah be pleased with him) told us that a letter came from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ to Bakr ibn Wa'il. We did not find anyone to read it to us until a man from Banu Dabbiyah read it to us, and they are called Banu al-Katib. It said: From the Messenger of Allah ﷺ to Bakr ibn Wa'il: Become Muslim and you will be safe.

narrators.name: Yusuf ibn Hammad
narrators.full_name: Yusuf ibn Hammad ibn Imran al-Qadi

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Qatadah is a known mudallis (type 3) and narrates using عَنْ (indirect transmission term), which requires caution despite his overall reliability
Indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) used from Said onwards create some ambiguity in the chain

potential_issues.issue: Mudallis narrator with indirect transmission: Qatadah
potential_issues.impact: Qatadah is classified as a Category 3 mudallis according to Ibn Hajar and narrates via عَنْ (indirect term). However, Qatadah is generally considered very reliable (Thiqah Thabt) by the majority of scholars. This combination requires noting but does not significantly affect the chain since Qatadah's reliability is well-established by many authorities.
From Said ibn Abi al-Hasan onwards, indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) are used, but given the general reliability of these narrators, this does not significantly undermine the chain's integrity.

Topics: Letter from the Prophet ﷺ to the tribe of Bakr ibn Wa'il
Call to Islam and promise of safety
Incident of the letter reaching Bakr ibn Wa'il

chainIssues: Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib is a known mudallis (type 3) and narrates using عَنْ, requiring caution
Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) from Ata' onwards create some ambiguity
The chain contains ambiguous phrasing 'or' (أَوْ) indicating uncertainty in transmission: 'عَنْ أَبِيهِ أَوْ عَنْ خَالِهِ' - unclear whether from his father or uncle

potential_issues.issue: Mudallis narrator with indirect transmission: Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib
potential_issues.impact: Ata' ibn al-Sa'ib is a Category 3 mudallis and narrates via عَنْ. This requires caution. However, he is generally considered acceptable (Saduq) by most scholars.

The text contains 'عَنْ أَبِيهِ أَوْ عَنْ خَالِهِ' (from his father or from his uncle), indicating the narrator was uncertain about the source of transmission. This creates ambiguity in the chain of transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms from mid-chain onwards
potential_issues.impact: The consistent use of عَنْ from Ata' onwards creates potential for disconnection, though the overall reliability of narrators somewhat mitigates this concern.

Topics: The believer is free from shame or disgrace

hadiths.english_translation: [This entry contains only a companion name with no complete hadith: Abdullah ibn al-Aswad ibn Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with him)]

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only a companion name with no chain of transmission or hadith text. It appears to be a section header or fragment rather than a complete hadith.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn al-Aswad: We came out to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ in a delegation of Banu Sadu' from the town. We came to him with Judhami dates as a gift for him. We came from the garments, garments of Banu Umayr from the town. We scattered the dates before the Messenger of Allah ﷺ on a mat. He took some of the dates with his hand, then said: What kind of dates are these? We said: These are Judhami dates. He said: May Allah bless the Judhami and in an orchard from which these came out, or a paradise from which these came out.

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn al-Aswad
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn al-Aswad ibn Sa'd al-Saduси

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Two unknown (Majhul) narrators in the chain: Muhammad ibn Khashish and Abd al-Hamid ibn Uqba
Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) from Muhammad ibn Amr onwards
Long and complex chain with intermediate transmitters (grandfather, grandfather's grandfather) that creates potential for disconnection

potential_issues.issue: Two unknown (Majhul) narrators: Muhammad ibn Khashish and Abd al-Hamid ibn Uqba
potential_issues.impact: These narrators are not known in the science of hadith narrators. The presence of unknown narrators significantly weakens the chain of transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms from the middle of the chain
potential_issues.impact: From Muhammad ibn Amr onwards, indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) are used, creating potential for disconnections.
The chain passes through multiple family generations with indirect transmission, increasing the risk of breaks in the transmission.

Topics: Delegation of Banu Sadu' visiting the Prophet ﷺ
Presenting Judhami dates as a gift
The Prophet's ﷺ supplication for blessings on Judhami dates
Incident of the Prophet ﷺ receiving gifts from delegations

hadiths.english_translation: [This entry contains only a companion name with no complete hadith: Abdullah ibn al-Mugheera ibn Abdullah al-Yashkuri (may Allah be pleased with him)]

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only a companion name with no chain of transmission or hadith text. It appears to be a section header or fragment rather than a complete hadith.

hadiths.english_translation: And from Yashkur of Bakr ibn Wail: Narrated by Ibn Numer: I said: O Messenger of Allah, guide me to a deed that will bring me closer to Paradise and distance me from Hell-fire. [The rest of the hadith is mentioned]

narrators.name: Ibn Numer
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Numer al-Qurashi

narrators.name: Al-Mugheera ibn Abdullah ibn Sa'd ibn al-Akhram

narrators.name: His father or his uncle
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Sa'd (father) or his uncle
narrators.alternative_names: Father of Al-Mugheera or his uncle

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Critical issue: Al-A'mash was doubtful about whether the narration was from the father or uncle (شَكَّ الأَعْمَشُ), creating a clear disconnection/ambiguity
Al-A'mash is a Type 2 mudallis and narrates via عَنْ (indirect transmission)
Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) create additional potential for disconnection

potential_issues.issue: Critical transmission uncertainty: Al-A'mash's doubt about the source
potential_issues.impact: The text explicitly states 'شَكَّ الأَعْمَشُ' (al-A'mash was doubtful) whether the narration came from the father or the uncle of al-Mugheera. This creates a fundamental disconnection in the chain and significantly weakens the hadith.

potential_issues.issue: Mudallis narrator with indirect transmission: Al-A'mash
potential_issues.impact: Al-A'mash is classified as a Type 2 mudallis and narrates via عَنْ (indirect term). While he is generally considered reliable (Thiqah), the combination with his documented doubt in this transmission further undermines the chain's integrity.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms from the chain
potential_issues.impact: The consistent use of عَنْ from al-A'mash onwards creates cumulative ambiguity in the transmission.

Topics: Request for guidance to Paradise and away from Hell-fire
Deeds that bring closer to Paradise

hadiths.english_translation: [This entry contains only a companion name with no complete hadith: Furat ibn Hayyan (may Allah be pleased with him)]

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only a companion name with no chain of transmission or hadith text. It appears to be a section header or fragment rather than a complete hadith.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Furat ibn Hayyan: The Prophet ﷺ ordered his killing, and he was a spy for Abu Sufyan. He passed by a gathering of the Ansar, and he said: I have become Muslim. This was reported to the Prophet ﷺ, and he said: We entrust some people to their faith, and among them is Furat ibn Hayyan. So he released him, and granted him land in al-Bahrain after that.

narrators.name: Ismail ibn Abd al-Malik al-Rabe'i
narrators.full_name: Ismail ibn Abd al-Malik ibn Rabe'ah al-Rabe'i

narrators.name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

narrators.name: Abu Ishaq

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ

chainIssues: Abu Ishaq is a known mudallis (type 3) and narrates via عَنْ (indirect transmission), which requires direct evidence of his meetings to be confirmed
Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) from Abu Ishaq onwards create potential for disconnection
The chain has strong early narrators (Shafi'i, al-Thawri) but weakens with ambiguous transmission from the middle onwards

potential_issues.issue: Mudallis narrator with indirect transmission: Abu Ishaq
potential_issues.impact: Abu Ishaq is classified as a Type 3 mudallis and narrates via عَنْ. Type 3 mudallis require explicit direct transmission terms to be accepted reliably. However, Abu Ishaq is generally considered trustworthy (Saduq) by most scholars, and al-Thawri, who narrated from him, is highly reliable and careful. This mitigates the concern to some extent.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms from middle of chain
potential_issues.impact: From Abu Ishaq onwards, indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) are used, though the reliability of these narrators somewhat offsets this concern.

potential_issues.issue: Text uses 'anna' (أَنّ) in presenting the hadith
potential_issues.impact: The hadith begins with 'أَنّ النَّبِيَّ' which indicates potential indirectness, though this is a common way of quoting companions' reports.

Topics: Incident of Furat ibn Hayyan being a spy for Abu Sufyan
Furat's conversion to Islam
The Prophet's ﷺ mercy towards sincere converts
Granting land in al-Bahrain by the Prophet ﷺ to Furat ibn Hayyan

While al-Hasan is reliable, the use of 'an' from him creates some ambiguity, though this is mitigated by his overall reliability.

Topics: The Prophet's ﷺ method of addressing the people

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Amr ibn Taghlib: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Among the signs of the Hour is the abundance of wealth, the prevalence of commerce, and the emergence of knowledge, or the pen. Amr said: If a man were to sell a trade, he would say: Until I consult the merchant of the tribe of so-and-so. And he would seek the great merchant in the air and would not be found.

narrators.name: Wahb ibn Jarir
narrators.full_name: Wahb ibn Jarir ibn Hazim al-Bajali

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: All narrators up to al-Hasan are reliable with direct transmission terms
Indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) only from al-Hasan onwards

potential_issues.impact: While al-Hasan is highly reliable (Thiqah Thabt), his use of 'an' from Amr ibn Taghlib creates minimal ambiguity given his established integrity and care in transmission.

Topics: Signs of the Hour: abundance of wealth
Signs of the Hour: prevalence of commerce
Signs of the Hour: emergence of knowledge
Signs of the Hour: prominence of the pen/writing
Incident of merchants being sought but not found
